body:
Here's the fix:
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2815

Columns of type _float_ seem to work as expected, though, at least with the SQLite backend.
I tested it by registering another column for the above table, which is defined by `id * 0.1` and making this column filterable of course.

With the name `Superset` now we have to allow for querying all database :)

But yeah it should work ok and fits the roadmap. As you said it would behave essentially like a table with a single metric and single time column. It might not be the best experience as a bunch of the fields in the explore view become obsolete, but would allow to have dashboard that mix elements coming from multiple data sources.

One more remark: If employed in a filter slice, all of the mentioned dtypes (str, int, bool, float) seem to work nicely. It is just the Filter Select in _explore_ that is affected.

For the filter slice, the issue with integers was addressed in #2004.
I just tested in MySQL and things work well for BIGINT. What's the type of `1` in that context?!

Can you try changing the line in the stacktrace from
`payload = json.dumps(datasource.values_for_column(column))`
to
`payload = json.dumps(datasource.values_for_column(column), default=utils.json_int_dttm_ser))`?

At least the error should show the type it's struggling with. Most likely some numpy related type.
Oh I understand now.
Here's the fix https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2816
if i set 'Page Length' ,the table view can not display all row. it only return limit  100 row

@xrmx here is my test code:
```
engine = create_engine(xxx)
conn = engine.connect()
dialect = MyDialect()
rs = dialect.get_schema_and_table_names(conn)   # works

insepector = sqla.inspect(engine)
rs = inspector.get_schema_names()   # works
rs = inspector.get_schema_and_table_names()   # AttributeError
```

```
def get_schema_names(self, connection, **kw)
def get_schema_and_table_names(self, connection, **kw)
```
The two functions have the same definitions and in the same class. Could it caused by `sqla.inspect`?
That's to say `get_schema_names` is been registered, and is the common function for all dialects, and `get_schema_and_table_names` is not common function? 
But I don't think `sqlalchemy` is designed to be inflexible
The error clearly shows there's no get_schema_and_table_names in what `sqla.inspect(engine)` returns. Also it's completely unrelated to superset since you are calling sqlalchemy straight.
#xrmx yes, it's slqalchemy's issue
@mistercrunch is it better than https://github.com/airbnb/react-dates ?
Did you update the python code but didn't rebuild the frontend?
@xrmx we need the component to handle time as well, not just date
is this the before or after gif?
LGTM 🚢
Addressed comments, merging

@mistercrunch: I now tested your solution in combination with a Postgres backend:

Integer columns now seem to work nicely. However, as I already anticipated somehow, boolean columns are not 100% compatible. While the lookup query apparently works, the distinct values are not displayed properly in the drop-down selector.
The selector correctly features two distinct options, however, they are both just blank.

![bool_filter_postgres](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1220356/26465506/bc5a130c-418b-11e7-8f25-3659cac7fb3d.PNG)

The two options seem to represent the correct `false` and `true` values (in alphabetic order), as can be confirmed by querying with any of these filter values set.

I got the idea that the difference between SQLite's and Postgres' boolean types is that the former uses `0` and `1` as representation, while the later employs `false` and `true`. So maybe it's all about casting these values to the strings that get printed in the selector list.

BTW: The very same behavior can be observed, when this (Postgres-)boolean column is included into a filter slice. Not quite sure whether I should file a new issue for this — apparently — Postgres-specific problem...

I can confirm that the fix works as expected. For the sake of completeness, I tested it with both SQLite and Postgres databases, although in my understanding this should not make any difference on this level.
Thanks for the quick fix!

Similarly, the verbose name could be used in the Filter Box.

Where is the verbose name used currently? I haven't seen it show up anywhere.
thanks for making those changes. a couple small comments, otherwise LGTM!

Hi Mistercrunch thank you for the suggestion. I tried the following code on the server where superset is installed in both the general python shell and the superset shell, after a kinit.

    from sqlalchemy import *
    from sqlalchemy.engine import create_engine
    from sqlalchemy.schema import *
    # Hive
    engine = create_engine('hive://localhost:10000/default', connect_args={'auth': 'KERBEROS', 
    'kerberos_service_name': 'hive'})
    logs = Table('my_awesome_data', MetaData(bind=engine), autoload=True)
    print select([func.count('*')], from_obj=logs).scal

sadly in both instances we get the same failure. End of the stacktrace:
```
    File "/var/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/thrift/transport/TSocket.py", line 132, in read
     message='TSocket read 0 bytes')
     TTransportException: TSocket read 0 bytes
```
Not sure where the issue is located, any further direction or help would be more than welcome.

I was looking for this as well, Thanks Arijana.
I noticed that the "Time Column" does not show the verbose name, it probably should be consistent across all column selects.

I don't think that the assumption that the `coalesce(verbose_name, non_verbose_name)` is unique is safe. If we agree that it isn't a safe assumption, the approach here is flawed. 

Originally I was picturing sending a mapping of non verbose to verbose name to the frontend, and having some utility method(s) there to replace the strings where they are displayed. `form_data` and dataframe series name would stay unchanged.

I know that for Airflow (another project I work on) we moved away from PyHive and into using Cloudera's Impyla to support Kerberized Hive since PyHive didn't support it at the time. In that case we do not use SQLAlchemy.

I think Impyla has issues with DBAPI compliance that make it incompatible with SQLAlchemy.

So. Two solution paths that are external to Superset:
* figure out how to Kerberize PyHive
* figure out how to SQLAlchemize Impyla

We're not the first people to attempt this, so there are related Github issues in the wild. If you do some research please paste your findings in this issue. Airbnb is interested as we're starting to think about Kerberize our cluster(s).

Latest I researched both solutions had shortcomings but seemed on the verge of breaking through.

It'd be nice to get coverage reports. I tried fixing coveralls yesterday by re-syncing the GH repo, it may come through in future PRs.

LGTM

@ascott the kanban is the `projects` label near the `pull requests` one :) My suggestion was to add a "improve frontend test coverage" and then track each file in a card in the kanban.

Hi all,

Connecting via PyHive to a Kerberized Hive should now be possible per this merged pull [request ](https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/pull/70 )and this stack overflow [answer](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41328652/query-kerberized-hive-with-sql-alchemy). The PyHive change at least seems to work on a toy cluster.

However, the problem in our case seems to be that our production HiveServer2 is set to http mode to support other services, while it needs to be set to binary.
 There is an open Jira [request ](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HIVE-5312)to enable Hive to allow both http mode and binary mode simultaneously and there is an open PyHive [issue ](https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/issues/69)to support http for PyHive. Current workaround is to setup another HiveServer2 instance.

Will close the issue and consider setting up Druid to connect to superset. 
Thank you for the help!

Note that Hive won't provide a good experience with Superset as it's just way to slow for most interactive use cases. At Airbnb we use Hive with SQL Lab, mainly to create summary datasets that we'll then query through Presto from the explore view.
Thanks for the fix!
LGTM
Hey Folks, I am getting the same error ... is it a Presto issue or Superset ???
Looks like the bug was fixed in the upstream dependency, so closing for now.
I am currently using the -t flag but still facing the same issue ... my queries are being interrupted around 50segs ... any tip on this please ?

Web requests are supposed to time out. Your webserver or proxy (if you use one) is likely set to timeout somewhere between 30-60 seconds. The real solution to this is to setup an async backend for SQL Lab.
Do you have a proxy in front of gunicorn? If so your proxy is timing out.
there was no spec for this component. looks it was a transient issue, tests are passing now.

Hey, thanks for the answer ... the solution for this is to use SUPERSET_WEBSERVER_TIMEOUT ... it is tricky as the two approaches for starting Superset are conflicting ... you EITHER use a config file OR use command line params (ex : -t) ... it is now going over 50segs ... THANKS !
![Current coverage](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/27990562/26704662/8d684b9a-46e5-11e7-9af0-4e6f780dfc11.png)

So the more I look at this Filter Box component the more I think it needs to be re-written to supports an array of heterogenous filters. I'm thinking that we probably want to reuse the `FiltersControl` in that context. `FiltersControl` is pretty intricate and seems like it should just work there, the only thing we're missing is the metrics-driven sort/histogram-background.
from flask_appbuilder.security.manager import AUTH_LDAP

Drill down assumes the framework is aware of hierarchies which Superset isn't at the moment. We encourage our users to slice and dice by entering the explore mode, applying filters and altering the "Group By" field which is pretty easy and very flexible. It's an open field instead of a guided flow.

From a dashboard, it might be unclear what the user expects when say clicking on a country. Should it filter on that country and refresh other charts in the dashboard to reflect that? Should it drill down on that one chart into one of the specified hierarchies? Should it drill down in the whole dashboard? Should it take the user to a report defined by the dashboard creator specific to that country, perhaps a "country scorecard"? Should there be a contextual menu offering these all/some of these options?
Please fix the 31 codeclimate issues and make sure the build passes
